(b) If Mavington and Harrison have the same velocity of money in Year <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, which country must have the higher money supply in Year <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? (d) Based on your answer to part (c), if the nominal interest rate is the same for both countries in Year <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, which country experiences the higher real interest rate in Year <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Explain.

(e) Based on your answer to part (c)(ii), if the expected inflation rate in Harrison in Year <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> was <math alttext="10%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, what would be the effect on real <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> as the economy adjusts to its long-run equilibrium? Explain.
